review_title: Overworked, Underpaid, and Ignored by Leadership
pros: Job security, State benefits, holidays, leave/vacation time.
cons:
Low pay, slow to no real advancement, increasingly expected to perform new duties in addition to current job role responsibilities without additional compensation. Staff constantly inform leadership/management that they are overworked, underpaid, and has voiced the same concerns for years--if lucky, concerns will take months to be officially recognized yet nothing is ever done to alleviate them. 

There is currently a mass exodus of very qualified, dedicated, and eager staff leaving the University after years of no or very minimal (1-3% every other year) cost of living adjustments that do not keep pace with increased costs in the area. The problem is compounded further by having remaining staff perform additional duties to maintain institutional stability with little or no increase in compensation--causing those staff to burn out even faster and seek employment elsewhere themselves.

pros: This was my first-ever paying job; I was an "office assistant" for the mailroom in VCU's Cary & Belvidere Residential Village--one of VCU's dorms. My position's main responsibilities were to receive, process and sort all mail and packages that came to C&B and distribute that mail not only to the student residents, but also the employees working in the Residential Life & Housing Office (also located in the C&B building) and the Chili's restaurant located next door. Fairly simple, routine work (even when we assistants had other responsibilities like checking students out of their dorms, and handling "special projects" that were loaded on us once or twice). The pay was pretty fair given the amount of work assistants usually had, and there was always opportunities to get overtime pay or increase your hours/pay due to one assistant leaving campus for holidays/personal reasons. Our supervisor is always the hall director, and my supervisor left over a year ago, but she was extremely nice, professional yet personable, and reliable. Whenever we brought an issue to her concern, she worked with us quickly to resolve it.
cons: Not really many cons. Really the only annoying aspect of working this post was having to resolve issues that could have easily been avoided if not for errors of the residents who expected mail/special packages. Like, who shows up late to receive a package (which we forwarded early on) that they knew they did not put the right name in the receiver field? Then there's always the pesky residents who don't respect mailroom hours, and those who fail to accept that USPS does not deliver mail on federal holidays.

review_title: Credentialed Humanities Professors held in total disregard
pros: Good students at VCU.  Good language/media center.  Student body sophisticated and sharp.
cons: I was told that the Department of World Studies was not a good place to be.  I thought that was because the person who criticized it did not have a teaching credential and probably was not serious about teaching language.  I joined the faculty in 2014.  I hold an M.A. from a well-regarded program in my discipline, and have continued to stay up to day and work in my field (translation).  There was no intellectual life in our department.  The tenured professors do not seem to bother keeping the library up to date on what the current texts are in the subjects they teach, so I had to order basic books of African literature even though a tenured prof. has published in that field.  No one observed my class, and it was given to me, then to someone else at the last moment, after it had filled, with no notice to me.  This may have been because another professor had to sue to get it.  Utter disregard for anything except money, extremely depressing and unfair working conditions.

pros: VCU is a pretty decent university with good benefits. Details depend on what you negotiate, hence it's impossible to generalize.
cons: Management in my unit is terrible with little interaction between leadership and faculty, but that is likely different in other units.

job_title: Visiting Assistant Professor in Richmond, VA
pros: Incredible students, vibrant art community, and lovely city.
cons: Unethical behavior in the administration and does not respect faculty.

pros: Nice people to work with
cons: I don't have any cons

review_title: They value personal connections over leadership skills.
pros: Depends on the leadership you are under.
cons: The lack of empathy for the lowest paid workers is incredible.

pros: Decent culture for the most part aside from a few in upper management

pros: Probably one of the best jobs on campus, you really don't have to do much other than help whoever comes along
cons: Does require being familiar with the library and moving around a decent amount

job_title: Executive Administrative Assistant in Richmond, VA
pros:
Good benefits
I cannot think of any other pros
cons:
Not much room for upward growth
Not much support for management
Pay for parking

pros: the job is flexible with classes
cons: there are no benefits for students

review_title: definitely has a lot of kinks to work out
job_title: Group Exercise Instructor in Richmond, VA
pros: I love working here because it makes me feel like a important part of my school.  I can stay involved and bring satisfaction to others in the VCU community.
cons: The gym is relatively new and still has a lot of miscommunication. Because I only come in to "work" and hour at a time I'm not as involved. But it is chaotic and they waste a lot of money on employee meetings where they really don't cover the information that is necessary for employees to know and understand there duties. There is no productive orientation that informs the employees, regardless of position, exactly how procedures and policies should be carried out (or maybe there just isn't an orientation for group ex instructors). It feels poorly run, but I would still say it is a fun place to work, if you can get past chaos.

job_title: Assistant Archivist, Part-time in Richmond, VA
pros: very chill, set up equipment sometimes
cons: not many hours, work was easy

review_title: Great university to start your career
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Richmond, VA
pros: diversity, make it real, supportive
cons: needs more international student attraction

job_title: Student Desktop Support Technician in Richmond, VA
pros: The people are always very friendly and very helpful, definitely lots of room to grow
cons: Not really anything to comment on here

pros: Great people, good benefits, flexible work schedule, great mentorship

job_title: Graduate Research/Teaching Assistant in Richmond, VA
pros: Nice place work and cheaper than DC

job_title: Clinical Research Associate in Richmond, VA

cons: Salaries are low, and the job is very demanding.

pros: Convenient street parking in the neighborhood

review_title: Nearly 20 years on the MCV Campus
pros: Great benefits package, collegial atmosphere, diverse community.  Access to considerable resources, including online training and extensive library/database.  Fantastic gym facilities for bargain prices.  Tuition waivers. Professional experience will vary greatly depending on position and Department.
cons: Lack of opportunities for internal growth--the only way to advance is to apply for another position.  There is lack of loyalty here...no guarantee that if you put in time and effort you will be rewarded for those efforts if applying for another position in same Department.  Parking expensive and often far from work location (you won't be running any errands on your breaks).  Starting to adopt very draconian attitudes towards time flexibility-but again this varies depending on where you are working.

review_title: Great place to work while in school
pros: I worked at the Campus Learning Center, a tutoring center within the university. I really loved all the people I worked with. It was inspiring to meet so many talented, smart, ambitious young people who were dedicated to helping their peers. Working with fellow students as a student was a really wonderful thing to be able to do, as I feel we were more much effective as such. The pay was pretty good considering it's just a part time job. Not long hours, and very flexible with your school schedule, obviously.
cons: Working with some of the faculty could be a challenge. I would often never see any response from them to my emails, or questions about their class. Many professors didn't seem to respect us a tutoring institution. This often tied our hands in our ability to improve our practices. Also, students will try to come in and get help on their homework, which is a big no no, so having to explain that to them would often get tedious.

job_title: Marketing Program Assistant in Richmond, VA
pros: As a student, I was able to get a job in a field Related to my major. Gained a lot of experience and the environment is a great one to work in. Promotions come if you work for it. The Gyms upper Management are great and Passionate about the gym. You can gain a lot of experience and build up your resume.
cons: pay is very low and not very competitive in the richmond environment. Yes you can get experience in a related field or have a really cool fun job on campus, but your hours are limited to part time, and they pay minimum wage for most jobs. In richmond you can find other jobs that pay a lot more. Also dealing with VCU's systems is never fun.

review_title: A Great Place to Learn & Grow
pros: VCU is an evergrowing campus of great people and even better educational opportunities. The students have kept me for years and I have established great relationships with administrative staff and faculty. The fluidity of information and knowledge sharing about the campus networks of students, faculty, and staff is unmatched and invaluable. I've been at VCU for over five years and in several capacities. I foresee no desire to vacate my position in the near future. There's plenty of career and educational advancement opportunity here.
cons: The value of diversity at VCU is understated often times and not included in many policy decisions. The high volume of students and organizational commitments tend to result in voluminous work loads that are not centralized (regarding the organizational structure).

review_title: A bunch of stuck-up professors who treat staff like second-class citizens
pros: Walkable campus, lots of paid time off, flexible scheduling
cons: Promotions based on education, not on job performance (meaning low performers who get their next level of education get promoted, before high performers). They have some really terrible people in leadership roles. You can't get a raise if so-and-so who has been there longer doesn't make that much money- even if you out perform or have more responsibilities. Staff treated poorly by professors. Professors are greedy- submit ridiculous claims on their travel forms and it gets processed (if you rock the boat you are considered not "customer service oriented"- meaning you call people out on fraud or you try to implement a process).

job_title: VCUarts Pre-College Summer Intensive Counselor in Richmond, VA
pros: As a student, working for VCU was relatively easy since I already knew where a lot of on-campus services were located and navigating the city became second nature. Promoting the college as a current student has been a natural part of the job, and I always give my honest impression of what attending VCU is like and how the city of Richmond interacts with the campus.
cons: Working for VCU means that I usually work with younger high school age people and their families,  so there can be days where the job gets to be a little repetitive and draining; Especially since the atmosphere is very academic and most prospective students want to secure a spot in a good school, so there's an added layer of pressure being brought into the conversation.

pros:
Specifically for the program I manage I am with an amazing group of people. My boss and coworkers make it worth the extra time you have to put in with students.
That being said, I also enjoy my time with the students in the program. 

Though I know both of the above things are not standard, where I am is great.

Also HR is actually pretty decent. The benefits are great and they do a good job of making sure you know what those entail
cons:
General issues in higher ed:
-as much bureaucracy as you can imagine and then some(avoid that by finding the right boss/being helpful and nice)
-enrollment ebbs and flows creates a lot of stress(plus online learning is giving us a run for our money)

review_title: Mostly positive with a few negative points
pros: The faculty are wonderful to work with. They are supportive and always keeping the students as their top priority. Tech support is awesome; they respond quickly to help resolve any issues.
cons: It’s difficult to find full time status as a professor. They would much rather keep you as adjunct faculty so the cost is down and they don’t have to pay benefits. Also, on-street parking is a disaster. Only option is to park in the parking deck but it can be costly over time and far away from your destination depending on your destination.

review_title: My experience as a grad student at the Dept of Pharmacology and Toxicology at VCU
pros: The best part about working as a grad student at VCU is that you are assured a solid education in becoming a knowledgeable pharmacologist.  Their training programs in demanding, but if you stick with it until the end, you will be an sought after expert in your field.
cons: As with most professions in life, people within the department can be political to the point of being conniving.  Some people are protective of their work and will do what is necessary to ensure that that their research stays funded and progressing.  There are no signs of open hostility, but you have to watch out for the subtle ones.

review_title: Good place to start or finish your career. The academy is very short and leaves much to be desired.
pros: Great benefits, generous leave, and a relatively low-stress work environment. I have not had a bad experience with mid-level management. The department recently adopted a very progressive grooming policy.
cons: The academy is very short and leaves much to be desired. 17 weeks leaves recruits feeling noticeably less trained than local and regional counterparts. Little independence with regards to discretion on misdemeanors. Equipment and uniforms feel like they are from the stone age.

review_title: Nice place to work except for the salary, which is the most negative aspect of working here - and it's a big negative.
pros: State benefits, telecommute once a week; working with many different technologies and great group of people
cons: Salary for IT workers is way below market, and the salaries are out of whack for what an individual does.  Employees that have been here a long time are making the same or much less than less experienced workers.  There are also two types of workers here - the ones who do all of the work and everyone else (the stereotypical state worker).

review_title: Large Organization, Each Department is Different
job_title: Animal Care Technician in Richmond, VA
pros:
Some departments are amazing, organized, and even feel like family. My wife works for a department on the University side and she has been there for almost 5 years. They've hosted baby showers, wedding showers, and all sorts of events for their employees! I worked part time for a number of years and full time for almost 2 years and had very different experiences in each department. 

Their benefits are AMAZING. If you get your foot in the door, move around, explore, and enjoy the opportunities they offer.
cons: Management in the Department of Animal Resources was a mess, but management at the Grace E. Harris Leadership Institute was incredible! I would highly recommend to stay away from DAR because there is too much drama and patriarchal/authoritarian style management.

pros: As a student, working here part time had to been the best thing for me. Thanks to their flexible scheduling, it was a great work/school balance. Also with a lot of face to face environment, it really helped me understand from an entry level standpoint of what a work environment would be like.
cons: If you are not very good at picking things up quickly, you might struggle a little since it is learning on the job. Training was very minimal, didnt really learn to much ,it is all on the job training in which you have to at times, figure out problems yourself causing you to waste a lot of time.

pros: Colleagues are extremely knowledgeable and friendly with diverse backgrounds. The collaborative environment at VCU is superb.
cons: Unfortunately, high competition also leads to the formation of siloes among research groups with similar interests yet dissimilar methods which can subvert the university's mission for ongoing innovation. High-productivity employees can trigger insecurity among colleagues - often expressed as skepticism, urges to "slow down", and dismissing new ideas - that results in the preclusion or cessation of collaborative projects.

review_title: Great atmosphere and time off but little advancement
pros:
- Vibrant college atmosphere
- Great holiday benefits and time off
- Access to the gym and library facilities as well as being able to take classes
- Lot of freedom to do work without being micromanaged
cons:
- Little available growth in advancement
- Stagnant salaries 
- Very political, big divide between upper management and other staff as well as staff and needs of students
- Lackluster attitude about position so always feeling the need to prove oneself
- Never got the sense that my manager understood what I actually did so praise felt shallow

pros: Good benefits, time off, training.
cons: Micro-management from hell!!  You are treated like a 10 year old, they watch your every move. Instead of treating you like an adult who they have entrusted with a gun to enforce the law you are treated like a toddler with scissors. Management is cocky and always looking for a reason to write you up. They don't want you to do police work they only want you to be seen and hand out hugs and lollipops.

review_title: Great place to get experience if you're seeking further education
pros:
Everyone is easy-going but is also responsible for their part. 
Since there are a lot of small labs, lab techs can learn a lot. 
State employee benefits.
cons:
Low pay. You can hardly make it on your own if you work as a lab tech. My salary is unusually high for a lab tech. 
Unless you're just getting experience to seek further education here, it's not a place to work for. I'm sure the pay is okay for other positions.

review_title: Good research opportunities and work-life balance
pros:
-VCU offers a vast network of employees with different expertise, so you feel that you can talk to different people and bounce around ideas about your professional interests and goals
-It's been my experience to have great co-workers who are generally sharp and down to earth
-There's lots of young talent which fosters a sense of rapid growth and change
-The institution engages with the community in various ways, which contributes to a good work culture
cons:
-I've found that promotions/upward mobility are not well integrated into the human resources structure
-There are many part time workers, limited to working 29 hours per week on average per year, which can be disincentivizing

pros: VCU has a great mission statement that I really believe in.
cons: Growing pains going from a regional university to an R1: Expects newer faculty to out-produce UVA, yet does not have the infrastructure in place to support these pursuits. Also, there is a lot of leadership turnover, which creates leadership voids. In addition, the "old school" professors hold on for dear life as the newer ones continue to cycle out.

pros: Great time off and benefits, enjoy the scope of work and the students, amazing diversity, a place with the resources (departments, professors, not $$) available that allows your imagination to create anything!
cons: Budget limitations, no upward mobility in job growth or salary increases, decision makers with no checks and balances, retaliation, expectations that employees constantly produce more while limiting their support, salaries well below market value, exempt employees have no work/life balance.

pros: I have found VCU a great place for faculty professional development and also teaching load. In the last ten years, VCU has made great progress in terms of research, and has recently (as of Jan 2011) been designated as a research one university. Teaching load is still heavy--as an urban research university.
cons: Teaching load can be quite heavy and sometime, student enrolled in the courses are very high. This does not give as much time for individual attention to students as much as the administration says it is doing.

pros: Very generous leave package, health insurance, and retirement. We don't have to work any time classes are canceled, which means we get 1-2 weeks paid time off around the holidays plus snow days and hurricane days. Also, VCU is enormous, so whenever you're ready to take the next step in your career, it's easy to find an opening of interest here. Coworkers are smart, professional, and friendly, and you're surrounded by cutting-edge research and artistic innovation.
cons: I haven't received any performance-based raises or cost-of-living increases. The road to promotion is longer than I feel is fair. Also I don't particularly like my job tasks.

review_title: Inconsistent management makes you fend for yourself
pros: Some of the coworkers I had were very talented at their positions and were unselfish in their work practices.  Pay and benefits were pretty good.
cons: Adherence by employees to policies is inconsistently enforced, which leaves a lot of unqualified people in their positions while removing ones who should remain employed.  Concerns about current conditions are often mishandled/overlooked by supervisors which results in our clientele placing blame on the associates they work most closely with, rather than the management.

pros:
Can be flexible about hours
The institution has very good benefits particularly because for insurance purposes you a part of the whole Commonwealth of Virginia employees as a whole. Also good discounts at local businesses.
cons: Working for a research laboratory you are at the whim of solely you laboratory principal investigator and your position depends on grant funding. This reduces job security and raises the risk of sudden terminations. Possibility of upward movement is very little and yet again depends on funding of faculty. In the present climate that funding seemed meager.  Experience and education can be of minor importance in overall compensation.

job_title: Labs/Classroom IT Support in Richmond, VA
pros: The best manager I have ever had, everyone is very friendly, I laugh more at work than anywhere else, very flexible work hours, always learning new things, being a state employee, all my co-workers are very helpful and friendly, just overall the greatest benefit seems to be the people I work with.
cons:
Job political drama, low pay, hard to get full time employment from part time.
And to reach 20 word minimum requirement for this, which I have now reached.

review_title: DO NOT WORK FOR VCU POLICE
pros: state benefits are great, people are pretty cool, if you like to ride bike it's great, decent stepping off point
cons: everything is wrong at the VCUPD the chief is a dictator who thinks the world revolves around him. They don't care about years of service, they actually try to get officers with time and service to quit or fire them.  If you don't fit the mold you're over looked for everything.  The administration just sucks all the way around. Literally 95 percent of the people that work there are looking for other jobs. You will hate your life if you work for VCUPD

review_title: I was able to teach eager students how to better their fitness through group exercise classes.
job_title: Group Exercise Instructor in Richmond, VA
pros: Fun, relaxed student atmosphere. They get you, and they cater to you. I gave them a very limited schedule, and despite the 50 or so other instructors they were able to carve out times in that day that worked with my schedule.
cons: No cons. Very fair. Very open. Some of the guys you work with are a bit overly macho, but overall it's an amazing place.

pros: Culture of diversity and inclusion, very stimulating environment with opportunities to learn and advance, and often have the opportunity to work with other peers.
cons: Although it was higher than minimum wage, the way was a little low. I also think that the very busy and hectic environment sometimes made it difficult to seek support when needed. Overall, however, it was a great experience and there isn't much to complain about.

pros: I have been able to draw back on some of my experiences as an RA to tackle new issues.  All in all, it was a rewarding job and I probably could have gotten more out of it.
cons: Higher-ups are a little too sensitive to those that are thin-skinned.  They don't take kindly to those who have unpopular opinions about policies, rules, laws, etc.

job_title: Teaching Assistant in West Chester, PA
pros: VCU as am employer for a current student is nice. They offer a $3000 a semester stipend for TAing. You are also teaching in the same campus in which you take classes
cons: Due to state regulations, hourly employees are limited to 26 hours a week so it is not a good choice once graduated. Professors also overlook examples of cheating that are brought to their attention.

pros: Excellent opportunity for growth and the good students really make it worthwhile although they are only a small proportion of the total class.
cons: Class sizes are exorbitant (350+ students) with no interaction, guidance, or assistance from the administration. Many students are completely unqualified to perform college level work.

pros: My specific experience was within a research lab in the Bio Department. As a whole the department is fairly relaxed, warm and inviting. The work was interesting, and biology office personnel are wonderful.
cons: Some internal academic drama existed from time to time. This can be avoided, but still very distracting. They also have a serious diversity issue. The researcher staff is almost 100% white.

review_title: Current employee of over five yearsGreat schoo
pros: Diverse university, with great faculty.  I have seen the university grow, attract outstanding faculty, and basically thrive under the new president.  VCU cares about their students and faculty and is doing much better in that regards.
cons: Salaries are lower than other institutions.  Huge inequity between MCV (medical) and Monroe Park campuses.  No tuition waiver for families at Monroe, but tuition waiver for MCV. No football team. Lack of performing arts facilities in comparison to other schools.

pros: I really enjoyed most of the other staff I worked with!
cons: Where do I start. I was let go from the university for reporting several issues made aware to me by staff members in the department. They were able to give me information I could verify and provide to senior administration who not only made excuses as to why they fired lower level staff for the same violations they excused for managers. But then fired myself and another manager who brought this to their attention.

review_title: VCU is a good place to work, but lots of red tape!  I retired in 2014, after 11 years .
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Richmond, VA
pros: It can work like living in a big city--you develop your own "neighborhood" of departments you need to work with, and the rest just doesn't affect you.
cons: It's like dealing with the government....things must be done in a certain way, usually including many forms, and no exceptions. If you're at MCV campus, parking is the other BIG issue.

pros: Management could have been better but at the end of the day I was fond of all of my bosses and they of me. Pay was pretty good for a college job and the work kept me busy. Learned a lot of office job skills.
cons: Management would stress out and take it out on student workers. We would get in trouble if we weren't constantly working, which was rough because sometimes there just wasn't anything to do at the moment.

job_title: PhD Student in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Independent and enjoyable work recruiting participants for a study on women's health. As a public university there are multiple departments, so I can not speak for all of them.
cons: Virginia Commonwealth University is not a top tier University, and as such does suffer on upkeep to some extent. Additionally, a lack of assistance with education while being employed through the university was disappointing to say the least.

pros: The students at VCU are amazingly inspiring - gritty, determined, many defying odds stacked against them to pursue higher education.
cons: VCU's infrastructure - processes and systems - are hugely inefficient and resistant to change, using the fact that VCU is a public institution as an excuse for mediocrity.

review_title: Good environment, pay is not great
pros: The environment is great. Working as a TA at the school you attend is awesome. You build connections with other students and with the teachers in the department.  Very flexible in terms of where/when you can work as long as the deadlines are met.
cons: The pay is poor, if you don't enjoy the work, I wouldn't recommend taking the position. There are usually very few hours/week available to work, so the paycheck is just a little bit of spending cash, it won't support anything.

pros: Great working for a large university and research institute.  I've grown in so many ways and have the best support team and have gained so much knowledge about addiction in general.  Our PI is from Houston, Texas is one of the best addiction psychiatrist in the country.
cons: No room for advancement.  You have to actually apply for another job in order to get a raise or be promoted.

pros: I'm not sure how helpful this review is, since I haven;t worked at VCU for 3.5 years now and many things might have changes. However, one thing is everlasting in this job - working with students is an extremely rewarding experience. Also, whenever employed full time at VCU, one can take up to two classes each semester for free.
cons: During my time at the USCA, they were experiencing a leadership crisis and a huge staff turnover. Not sure if that is still the case, though.

review_title: Up and coming university with room to grow
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Richmond, VA
pros: VCU is a rapidly growing university with more opportunities to try new things than may be present at other more established universities.  There is a real sense of excitement on campus because of this culture of growth.
cons: The salaries are not as high as other universities and while its standards are rapidly rising there are still some areas that could be improved.

job_title: Postdoctoral Research Fellow in Richmond, VA
pros: Large university, with a backdrop of a nice city. Has an excellent medical school, hence any research related to the filed of medicine has great potential.
cons: You job satisfaction depends highly on the department you work for. Not all departments are equal here.

pros: Good benefits and education advancement. Salary with excellent health care and conveniently located in the heart of the city of Richmond Virginia. Moving to new department headquarters soon.
cons: Low on the salary scale compared to other local agencies. Split campus duties include medical campus which is different police work than municipal agencies

pros: Very relaxed and welcoming work environment where staff is valued just as much as the work that needs to be done. Cares about your professional development, even if outside of assigned position.
cons: Some employees are overworked and underpaid, expectations can be aa little unclear and without structure at times.

review_title: Good place to work if you are still in school
pros: Lay back, good when you are in school since you get sick days and personal time every year and management seems to not care since it's your time (depending on dept. you work for), variety of food to eat for lunch, job security, mostly nice people to work with and relax atmosphere.
cons: Pay, not great for advancement or career growth

pros: An urban higher ed institution that has a strong research culture and an excellent teaching service. VCU status has recently been classified as having very high research activity by the Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education.
cons: The campus is dispersed as it is located in downtown Richmond. The campus is divided into two subcampuses: the MCV campus for medical and health science schools and the Monroe Park campus for the remaining fields of study. Parking is very difficult.

review_title: It's good to work at one of the largest universities in the state.
pros: Good benefits. It's nice to have the long winter break for Chriatmas to New Years.  There's a culture that is always striving to be bigger, better, faster. They like to be in the leading edge on technology.
cons: You may have a long walk from where you park to where you work. Pay not as much as the private sector. Since the organization is large, change can be slow.

review_title: The VCU School of Medicine is a great place to work!
pros:
1.  academic medicine is an exciting environment
2.  VCU Health is a fairly "recession-proof" work environment
3.  the University and the Health System off a lot of job advancement opportunities
cons:
1.  employee parking is lousy for the most part, and expensive
2.  VCUHealth employees don't receive the same more generous benefits as VCU employees do

pros: Motivating environment, very ambitious personalities come through the office!
cons: Answering phones to parents upset about their children's admission status into various programs is stressful. Students have no say in these decisions yet we are the ones answering calls to distressed parents.

pros: Flexibility, diversity, interesting work, good pay, great coworkers, interesting events happening all the time. Making a difference in people's lives is also a plus.
cons: Poorly maintained facilities/buildings, faculty sometimes behave badly with zero consequences, crime is a thing around campus. Strange political climate, some culture issues depending on what department you're in.

pros: Great infrastructure, a university with a research reputation on the up, very accommodating to your schedule. The lab I worked in was very diverse but everyone got along well, no nasty politics of any sort, so the work environment is very professional but very friendly as well.
cons: Richmond can be a little dangerous, although very little crime happens around the medical campus. But if you're on the other campus, it can get a little strange at time.

job_title: Brand Content Strategist in Richmond, VA
pros: The administration is as hands on as a school needs to be without micro-managing the classroom. Students we're engaged and passionate about the course work.
cons: students need more technical skills to truly thrive in today's workplace. Parking isn't provided, some material needed to be purchased by the faculty... Better pay might make for better adjunct faculty.

job_title: Senior Student Manager in Richmond, VA
pros: Educational, potential for advancement, latitude in performing duties, trust by upper management of decisions made by employees, variety of daily work.
cons: Study jobs do not continue past graduation, difficulty to find parking, city can be abrasive for some people, set standards for incremental raises.

pros: I was a storage processing assistant so I worked in the storage building for the VCU library. My job was very calm and quiet and extremely flexible. Probably the most flexible job I'll ever have. Pay was good compared to other work-study jobs and my co-workers and supervisors were all really kind people.
cons: No immediate cons but it's not likely that you can make your way up and earn more money in the process.

pros:
it is a great place to wok.Depending on your role you will be working in a diverse and multi-cultural background .  From an Engineering standpoint there are many opportunities to learn a lot of skills 
again depending on what your interest is .It has a vibrant campus which is in the heart of Richmond Vrginia .
cons: I don't really think there are any down sides of working at such an establishment

pros: Overall, this is a great place to work. The benefits are good, and most of the people are down to earth. If you are interested in furthering your education, you can take up to 18 credits a year for free, which is excellent.
cons: Overall, the compensation is lower than the private sector, but many of the state benefits make up for that. Also, education tends to be slow moving, so expect that.

pros: state retirement, sick days automatically granted, family and personal days automatically granted, excellent benefits, flexible working schedule available if needed, pays for 2 classes per semester, winter vacation at Christmas
cons: salary low, raises are dependent on general assembly decisions, must pay for our parking, not mush room for advancement in my department

pros:
The faculty members are very supportive of the students, and there are always opportunities to find projects to build your CV.  

I get a pretty decent stipend as a graduate student and all my courses are paid for.
